ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: recorded lecture
recorded lecture and virtual seminar
Virtual Lecture Asynchronous
Lecture
Virtual seminars were paired with weekly lectures.
Recorded lecture
recorded lecture, live colloquia

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to read works of history and political philosophy, and talk and write about them afterward.
I learned to closely analyze texts and make arguments about them.
I learned how to consider politics in an ancient and modern context. I also learned how to maintain intelligent discussion and create thoughtful responses to what others have said.
I learned to close read with a better understanding of the author's purpose and nuance, to write with a more controlled and humble tone, and discuss reading content with more depth with peers.
Incredible theme/pattern tracking throughout texts (applicable in all humanities classes); understanding how history has been communicated & ways political thought has evolved over time

Writing skills
Logic chain
I learned to parse through every sentence and left with a greater appreciation for not only history's stories but those who tell them.

I developed my writing/analytical skills considerably in the area of history/politics, which is a type of writing I wasn't very familiar with when I began the course. I also developed my in-class spoken skills.

More than my other DS courses, H&P taught me to put various authors in conversation with each other, and to analyze the contrasts between them. I studied foundational historical and political works, which I think will be very useful as I proceed in my academic career at Yale.
I learned how to read and analyze historical texts and write historical papers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussions were very interesting and insightful.

I like how Prof. Thompson mixes lectures and discussions in our seminars. Her lectures are very enlightening and there are always good points. I have much better grasps on the materials after she talks about them in seminars. She is also good at facilitating discussions so that everyone can contribute. I think the discussion starter is especially helpful. No major weaknesses.
The only weakness of this course was that it was online. I loved everything about the course except I wish that I could have discussed with my classmates face to face.

The strength was that we discussed in depth about certain passages of the text to really understand the nuance rather than a superficial understanding. A weakness is that when we do such in-depth analysis, we could not cover a lot of the assigned reading.

strengths: Prof. Thompson is an incredible professor who is very knowledgeable; the texts are fascinating; youll definitely get a lot out of it if you engage even with only 50% of the texts

weaknesses: constant heavy workload
Small class is good
There were no weaknesses!  This was a terrific class!

The strengths of this course were the instructor and the students who were all very engaged and enhanced my learning. The weaknesses were definitely related to the online format of the class, which I believe prevented the class from having the dynamic it could have had if we were in person.

Strengths: student-driven discussion with sufficient input from the instructor, texts often put in conversation with each other, wide variety of viewpoints studied
Weaknesses: paced a bit too fast to fully delve into the material, could have applied material to contemporary issues more
Sad having to do the course online, but Prof. Thompson made the format enjoyable.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: PDF books were very accessible, but reading online PDFs was not the greatest. Not only could annotations not be made, but it contributed to the excess of screen time.
Virtual DS ends up nicely.
The lectures worked although they were not ideal. The seminars worked as well, but it was a lot harder to feel engaged in the discussion when it was online.
I think it might be helpful to have a uniform way of posting lectures and submitting assignments/papers. There were frequent confusions on where the lectures are posted.
Good seminar virtual

I believe that most aspects of online learning are not ideal, though it is difficult to see how they could be improved. I think maybe having more time dedicated to students and instructors getting to know each other would help to counteract the distance that online learning can create within a class.

I really enjoyed our virtual seminar meetings, although I thought a break in the middle might have made it easier to focus for the entirety of each seminar. Additionally, I think the discussion post feature of Canvas could have been utilized more.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, Directed Studies is an incredible and unique experience.

Definitely! DS H&P with Prof. Thompson is one of the most enlightening experiences I've had. She is good at both lecturing and facilitating student discussions. Reading and papers are manageable and she grades fairly on the papers with helpful comments.
Yes! DS helped me grow so much as a student and a person, and Professor Thompson is a caring and intelligent teacher.

Yes, I'd recommend this to any student who wants to develop reading and writing skills. Even though classical studies is not your primary interest, it is a very interesting class that will be beneficial to all future classes.
Yes!
Yes
Yes!  H&P with Professor Thompson is always an amazing experience.  Every seminar she opened my eyes to new ways of approaching different texts and understanding the authors' intent.
Yes--though it was very challenging, I feel it was effort well-spent, and I can see clear improvements in my writing and analytical thought after this class.

I would recommend this course as an excellent survey of early historical and political thought for anyone seeking to pursue the pre-law track. Despite its large workload, I think this course thoroughly prepared me for any political science courses I may take in the future, and helped me to become a better writer.
Yes! If you are at all interested in the humanities, this course, and the Directed Studies curriculum in general, is an immersive experience that you won't get anywhere else.
